awd_titl_txt: Building our Net: Fostering Resilient Indigenous Scientists and Increasing Undergraduate Retention in the STEM Field through Scholarships and Mentoring
awd_abstract_narration:
This project focuses on students at Northwest Indian College (NWIC) who are pursuing the degree of Bachelor of Science in Native Environmental Science (BSNES).  The vast majority of NWIC students are Indigenous (American Indian or Alaskan Native). The goal of the project is to increase the recruitment, retention, student success, and graduation of low-income academically-talented NWIC students with demonstrated financial need who are pursing baccalaureate degrees in the fields of Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM).  To retain these students in STEM, the project supports reduction of students' financial barriers through scholarships, including academic support and community building for the entire BSNES population, and provides incentives for behaviors known to increase retention.  Through these efforts, the project will increase the number of American Indians and Alaska Natives entering the field of Environmental Science and continuing to graduate school or entering the workforce.

The college and academic program are well-positioned to support Indigenous students majoring in Native Environmental Science because the college's mission and the program's design directly support advancing Native American education.  The Native Environmental Science program has a strong record of supporting and graduating Indigenous students who are STEM majors.  The project focuses on recruitment of new Indigenous students  who will major in STEM through a Student Ambassador program and the use of digital storytelling, where scholars share their research and goals with neighboring high school students at the tribal school.  An innovative evaluation methodology based on the Indigenous Evaluation Framework will also contribute to an understanding of how to frame and assess education of Indigenous students.  The project will disseminate findings to tribal colleges and other minority-serving institutions through academic papers, conference presentations, and development of a manual highlighting recruitment, retention, curricular and extra-curricular practices that best support Indigenous students as scientists and scholars.  The project is in a position to generate significant and useful data about Indigenous students pursuing STEM degrees, a population that is not often studied and is critically underrepresented in STEM.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to support and serve Indigenous students in the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) field.

Specifically, the project had four goals:

  • To improve educational opportunities for American Indian/Alaskan Native Students in the STEM field.
  • To increase the student retention rate for students in the Bachelor of Science in Native Environmental Science (BSNES) program.
  • To increase the number of American Indian/Alaskan Native undergraduates in the STEM field and increase the matriculation of students into STEM graduate programs.
  • To identify and promote best practices in tribal college settings and for institutions serving Indigenous populations to transform STEM education.

As a result of this project, Northwest Indian College (NWIC) supported 83 individual BSNES students through direct financial scholarships and provided support and community building for the entire BSNES population. The project fostered and sustained program excellence and was designed to increase student opportunities to actively participate (and lead) research in the STEM field that engages with Indigenous Knowledge Systems. 

A significant part of this project was to reduce financial barriers for Indigenous students in the STEM field. The distribution of financial support had an important impact on our students who have disproportionately high financial needs. Over the course of five academic years, we provided approximately one million dollars in direct financial aid to 83 academically-talented Indigenous science scholars. Over the course of this project, 45 of these scholars earned their Bachelor of Science degree, while the other scholars continue in their educational journey.  Fifteen of these students matriculated into graduate school in the STEM field, while the others entered workforce in the STEM field, predominately in tribal natural resource management. 

This project increased the year-to-year retention rate of students enrolled in the BSNES program at NWIC to 87%.  This increase in retention occurred through improved student support, including financial support, advising support, academic support, and cohort building.

Through increased retention efforts, our project goals increased the number of American Indians and Alaska Natives entering the STEM field and continuing on to graduate school or entering the workforce.  In addition, with the support of this grant, the BSNES students contributed to the STEM field through participation in STEM conferences and participation in academic publications co-authored with faculty advisors, thereby contributing to a widening understanding of multiple knowledge systems and ways of knowing the STEM field.

The impact of the STEM scholarships and related programming has far-reaching impacts.  The students who earned STEM scholarships represent a diverse range of Indigenous nations, including students from the Coast Salish tribes of Lummi Nation, Nooksack, Swinomish, Tulalip, Quinault, and Nisqually as well as students representing Yakama Nation, Nez Perce, Walker River Paiute Tribe, Lake Superior Chippewa, Tsaagweidi (Tlingit), Tiits Giit a Naay (Haida), Cherokee Nation, Navajo Nation, Peoria Tribe of Oklahoma, Anishnabe, Potawatomi, Alutiiq, Warm Springs, Northern Arapaho, Wasco, Umatilla, and Colville.  This diversity of Indigenous Nations represented in our S-STEM scholars provide a large footprint of impact, as each of these students contribute to positive impacts in their own home communities, and serve as role models for positive growth in their own respective communities.  

A key finding from this project is that those scholars that took a leave of absence, for a variety of reasons (personal, health, family, etc), ended up coming back and completing the degree.  Through re-entry conversations and interviews, the S-STEM award was a big factor in this return ? providing a safety net both financially and personally - through an established network of communication and support.

 


Last Modified: 11/27/2022
Modified by: Emma S Norman
